question: Question_07_(b)
sols:
If we divide all the even integers by two, we obtain all the integers.
To turn this into a map, we just need to say what we'll do with the odd
integers (anything would work, for example mapping all the odd integers
to the number 4 or as we present below, map them to the rounded half).

\begin{align*}
g: \mathbb{Z} &\to \mathbb{Z}\\
n &\mapsto \begin{cases}
\,\,\,\frac{n}{2} & \text{if } n \text{ is even;}\\
\frac{n-1}{2} & \text{if } n \text{ is odd.} 
\end{cases}\end{align*}

\textbf{Proof:} \emph{recall that this question didn't ask for a proof,
just the answer. Since the proofs are of a difficulty that you are
expected to be able to handle in this course, we present them here for
completeness.}

This function is clearly surjective since any integer \emph{n} is the
image of the integer 2\emph{n}. Now the function is not injective since
\emph{g(3) = g(2) = 1} (or more generally since g(2\emph{k}+1) =
g(2\emph{k}) = \emph{k} for any integer \emph{k}).
hints:
Recall that surjective means that all integers have to be the image of
some integer by the function $f$ and not being injective means that there
are at least two integers which are mapped to the same integer.
